folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Bleecker Street., Manhattan, NY
text:
Sixth Avenue-Extension, south from Bleecker Street, showing the slice-through that eliminated Hancock Street from Manhattan maps. Under construction is the Municipal subway. The center foreground was the former site of the R. C. Church of Our Lady of Pompeii (St. Carlos Missionary Fathers). On the left are several six story apartment houses, that formerly bore No's. 1-3, 5-7 and 9-13 Hancock Street. These will remain, acquiring 6th Avenue identities. On the extreme right is the rear of the Downing Street site, upon which in 1941 will rise a modern apartment structure, No. 10 Downing Street. The new west line of the Avenue will run there, forming the easterly side of this building plot. The partially demolished 6-story structures shown there front on West Houston Street. They will remain. Through the center is Congress Street, a short thoroughfare extending south of West Houston to King Street. This is to be included in the new thoroughfare.

P. L. Sperr

May 12, 1927
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Bleecker Street., Manhattan, NY
text:
Dipping Tar for Subway work-- East side of Sixth Avenue, south of Bleecker Street.
October 11, 1928.
P.L.Sperr, photographer.
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Bleecker Street., Manhattan, NY
text:
S.E. corner of Sixth Avenue and Bleeker Street.
April 3, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Bleecker Street., Manhattan, NY
text:
Sixth Avenue, north from Bleecker Street, showing the Sixth Avenue "El" bend at W. 3rd Street. Carmine Street is at the left and Minetta Lane at the right. View 2 is limited to the Minetta Lane to W. 3rd Street frontage. This was developed as a play area in 1938. The old type houses shown are No's. 136 and 138 W. 3rd Street. Above same is the distinctive apartment house, No. 1 Fifth Avenue.

March 25, 1933
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

text:
22 to 12 Downing Street, south side, west of and towards Sixth Avenue.
April 3, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO
BE EAST AND WEST

folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Bleecker Street., Manhattan, NY
text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from Bleecker Street, showing that odd corner formed by Minetta Street (right) and Minetta Lane (left). Nestling here was the former Minetta Place. This would be about where the tool shacks appear. Most of the buildings are gOne, though two remain, No's. 20 and 22 Minetta Street. The vacant space to the left of these is to be the site of a new 6-story apartment house according to the New York Times of December 16, 1939. Across this cleared site are buildings on the north side of Minetta Lane. Towering above are apartments on Washington Square. Behind the sign board on the right is the peculiar bend in Minetta Street.
April 13, 1940
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
(3)
A southeastward view towards Minetta Lane (center) showing the aforementioned apartment house completed. West 3rd Street is on the left and does not appear. To the right is Minetta Street flowing into 6th Avenue at Bleecker Street. The latter is not
included.
August 3, 1940
P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.
